title: (x) Icelandic Newspaper/Medical Ad - Today Sans/Arepo {William, Yves}
content:
I've recently found some _lovely_ faces. I do hope someone can help identify them? I'd be delighted. The first is from the Icelandic newspaper Morgunbladid:
<img> The second comes (oddly) from some sort of herb advert. For ages, it was wonderfully used in the british Total Film magazine though I could never figure out what it was.
<img>
Thanks so much for the help!
author: dancetoherpulse

comments.content: Nathan, I don't think img tags work on Typophile... Use the "upload attachment" button instead.
The lower one is Cronos, from Slimbach and Adobe.
hrm, ive looked at cronos before, its very similar, but not quite it (notice the w's are different, e.g. in the 'newsweek'), thanks though.

Oops. [Today Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116102233/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/today-sans/)   
   
I guess Hrant & co were right about Cronos being so influenced by today sans.

aw, splendid, i've found it! it's Volker KÃ¼ster's Today Sans Serif [http://www.veer.com/results.asp?image=EFT0000415](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116102233/http:/www.veer.com/results.asp?image=EFT0000415)
haha, sorry, you beat me to it, much appreciated.

Heads are set in Sumner Stone's [Arepo](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116102233/http:/www.stonetypefoundry.com/html_pages/ArepoOverview.html). More info in [this thread](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116102233/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/6692.html).
Wow, Arepo is elegant. I like the way it has touches of old style in with the bodoni look. I wonder why it isn't used more.
